results.title: Land rights views: Number 9, July 1998
results.brief_description: A yearly magazine program dealing with issues associated with the Northern Land Council. This edition includes reports on the battle for Beetaloo, the Croker Island native title pearl deal, Kakadu management, Sorry day and the Barunga festival. Music from various Aboriginal acts is also featured.

results.title: Land rights views: Number 8, July 1997
results.creator_credit: Northern Land Council Media Unit and Northern Land Council
results.brief_description: A yearly magazine program dealing with issues associated with the Northern Land Council. This edition includes reports on the Jawoyn ‘Five Year Plan’, the Crocker Island seas native title claim, the Wik decision, a social impact study in the Kakadu region, the fight to save Railway Dam in Darwin and the ‘Black economy’ in the Top End. Music from various Aboriginal acts is also featured.

results.title: 3-in-1: the path to reconciliation
results.brief_description: This video contains a compilation of three videos produced for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to explain its vision and some of the major issues affecting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. “Walking together, produced by National Recording Studios, is an introduction to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation; “Talkin’ Business”, produced by OZIRIS Productions, explains the Council’s consultation program, vision and key issues; “Making things right”, produced by National Recording studios, looks at reconcilation after the High Court decision on Native Title. Includes a 60 page guidebook, “The Path to reconciliation: Issues for a people’s movement”.

results.title: The Last Tasmanian : A story of genocide
results.brief_description: This is the story of the swiftest and most comprehensive genocide on record. The Tasmanian Aborignals were an isolated people until British colonisation began. Deliberate government policy and actions meant that a whole society and culture was virtually wiped out within the lifetime of Truganini, known as “The Last Tasmanian”. This documentary takes a conservative position on Tasmanian Aboriginality, which has since been challenged by descendants of indigenous ancestors.
results.title_for_label: The Last Tasmanian : A story of genocide

results.title: Shifting Sands: from sand to celluloid continued...
results.brief_description: This video contains six short films about the lives of Aboriginal Australians living in today’s society. “Tears”, directed by Ivan Sen, is the story of a teenage couple as they walk from their northern mission station to a bus stop and await a new life with the girl’s father, who perhaps doesn’t know they are coming and who probably doesn’t care anyway. “My colour, your kind”, directed by Danielle McLean, is the journey through and to uncertainty of an albino Aboriginal girl who escapes from a severe Catholic mission to trek barefoot in a nightie across the outback. “Passing through”, directed by Mark Olive, a young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past? “Promise”, directed by Mitch Torres, is the tale of an old woman overseeing her grand-daughter making damper when she is asked how it came to be that she was betrothed at a young age. “My bed, your bed”, directed by Erica Glynn, in an isolated desert community, the time has come for two young people promised to each other under traditional law to move in together. Things don’t run as smoothly as they might. “Grace”, directed by Wesley Enoch, Grace is a middle-aged woman, living a comfortable life but when she returns to the mission where she grew up for the funeral of her sister she is confronted by the family she never met.

results.title: Tripwire
results.creator_credit: Valerie Morton, David Hirst and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: A character and action driven true-life adventure documentary looking at the Australian Armys secret Norforce unit that forms this Island continents first line of defence across the remote Kimberly region and the Northern Territory. Norforce is also one of the msot dynamic experiments in inter-racial relations as the unit is made up of both white and Aboriginal Australians where the soldiers learn essential survival skills from each other. Narrated by Archie Roach, and featuring the music of the Warumpi Band.

results.title: After Mabo
results.creator_credit: John Hughes, Debra Annear, Richard Frankland and Mirimbiak Nations Aboriginal Corporation
results.brief_description: Filmed over a ten-month period throughout Australia, this probing documentary examines the political controversy surrounding Native Title and the Australian Federal Governments proposed amendments to the Native Title Act, 1993. It follows the Indigenous representatives in their attempt to fight the amendments in the media, in the bush, and in the halls of Parliament House, Canberra. This video is ideally suited to students of history, politics and Aboriginal studies. NOTE: There are no discussion notes included with this title.

results.title: Namatjira the painter
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, Ralph Foster and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Traces the life and artistic development of the Aboriginal painter, the late Albert Namatjira. His environment, his introduction to painting, his subsequent success with beautifully original landscapes and his influence on fellow Aborigines are recorded. [Rev. ed. 007430]

results.title: No way to forget
results.brief_description: Based on Richard Frankland’s experiences as a field officer during the Royal Commission into Aboriginal custody, this film follows the journey of Shane as he drives from Swan Hill to Melbourne after a day in the field. During the night, his experiences play on his mind and imagination. He will be haunted by what he has seen.

results.title: Mabo: the life of an Island man (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Denise Haslem and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Filmmaker Trevor Graham documented the only film record of the Mabo proceedings in 1989 in his film “Land Bilong islanders” and in the process established a friendship with Eddie Koiki Mabo. This film documents the extraordinary life of a man so passionate about his family and home that he fought an entire nation and its legal system. Sadly, he died five months before the High Court upheld his claim for “Native Title”. However he cemented a place in Australia’s history. This documentary won an AFI award in 1997.
